thread.title: Mark Helfrich's big pay raise earns Ducks coach a big bump in coaches' salary ranking
thread.title_full: Mark Helfrich's big pay raise earns Ducks coach a big bump in coaches' salary ranking | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Greif | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Mark Helfrich's big pay raise earns Ducks coach a big bump in coaches' salary ranking
text:
EUGENE — With a 3-2 start to the 2015 college football season, Mark Helfrich's Oregon Ducks remain on the outside looking in on this week's rankings.
The five-year, $17.5-million contract extension awarded to Helfrich in February , however, has put him closer to the nation's top-25 among his peers.
The $3.15 million that Helfrich will earn in the first year of that extension ranks him 30th among 121 Football Bowl Subdivision head coaches whose salaries were provided in the latest USA Today survey of coaching salaries that was released Thursday. The salaries of seven coaches at private universities — such as Steve Sarkisian at USC — were not included.
It represents a big bump for Helfrich, whose $2 million salary last season ranked him 51st nationally , the lowest of any top-25 ranked team at the time. In his first season as head coach in 2013, Helfrich earned $1.8 million.
The Ducks rewarded him with a new deal (read the contract here) on Feb. 9, less than a month after leading the Ducks to a school-record 13 victories, an appearance in the College Football Playoff national championship game and soon after he was a finalist for two coach of the year honors, by the Football Writers Association of America and the Maxwell Football Club.
The deal escalates by $150,000 per year until 2019-20, when he tops out at $3.85 million.
Helfrich, who has a 27-6 career record, now ranks as the fourth highest-paid Pac-12 Conference coach, trailing Washington's Chris Petersen ($3.4 million), UCLA's Jim Mora ($3.35 million) and Arizona's Rich Rodriguez ($3.23 million). Helfrich is 7-4 against coaches ranked ahead of him in USA Today's latest survey .
Oregon State coach Gary Andersen's $2.45 million salary this season ranks 45th.
As is custom with most coaching deals, Helfrich's offers big-paying incentives for the Ducks' academics and on-field performance. He'll also earn bonuses if Oregon wins 10 and 11 games, compared with his former deal, which kicked in a bonus only at 12 victories. A national title will earn him $500,000, double what his previous deal would have paid out.
At $7.08 million, Alabama's Nick Saban is America's highest-paid college football coach. Trailing him is Michigan's Jim Harbaugh, earning $7.0 million in his first year at his alma mater.
